## Data Use in Academia {auto-animate="true" auto-animate-easing="ease-out"}

::: {.column width="40%"}
::: {data-id="dim14" auto-animate-delay="0.6" style="background: #ef476f; width: 300px; height: 400px; margin: 40px; font-size: 50px; text-align: center; color: black;border:  3px solid black "}
</br> </br>

Academia
:::
:::

::: {.column width="40%"}
-   Are academics using data produced by country?

-   Lack consistently updated measure of data use
:::

## Overview {.smaller}

::: incremental
-   Create measure of [data use by academia]{style="color: purple; font-weight: bold"} for each country

-   Train [machine learning model]{style="font-weight: bold"} on [900 human coded]{style="text-decoration: underline"} articles

    -   87% accuracy when tested against hold-out set of [2,600 human coded]{style="text-decoration: underline"} articles
    -   Country rankings correlated 0.99

-   Apply to corpus of 1 million academic articles

    -   Database: [Semantic Scholar (s2orc)]{style="font-weight: bold"}
    -   Language: English
    -   Time period: 2000-2020
    -   Subjects: Medicine, Economics, Psychology, Sociology, Political Science
:::

## Key Findings

::: incremental
-   Measures strongly correlated with: [GDP per capita, population, Statistical Performance Indicator (SPI) score ]{style="font-weight: bold"}

-   More surveys = More academic output

-   High income countries produce [ 50% of all articles ]{style="color: blue"} using data

    -   Low income countries produce [ 5% ]{style="color: orange"}
:::

## Machine Learning Approach {.smaller}

::: incremental
-   Used [BERT model]{style="color: red"} [(bidirectional Encoder Representations for transformers)]{style="color: green"}

    -   Natural Language Processing model developed by Google initially trained on Toronto Book Corpus and Wikipedia

    -   Further trained model on 900 hand coded articles from Mturk

    -   Tested on 2,600 articles held out of training

        -   [87% accuracy]{style="color: blue"} in classifying data use
        -   When aggregating results to country level, total number of articles using data [correlated 0.99]{style="color: blue"} with human rated totals

-   Country of study classified using Regular Expressions and SpaCy python package
:::

## More Surveys = Higher Academic Output {.smaller}

::: incremental
-   Do increases in [availability of data sources]{style="color: green; font-weight: bold"} lead to more [articles using data]{style="color: blue; font-weight: bold"}?

-   Examine using linear regression:

    -   Take advantage of longitudinal nature of data
    -   [Logged number of academic articles per year]{style="color: blue; font-weight: bold"} on LHS
    -   Hold constant [population size, GDP per capita]{style="color: purple; font-weight: bold"}, [country fixed effects]{style="color: orange; font-weight: bold"}, [time effects]{style="color: brown; font-weight: bold"}
        -   Use only within country variation in availability of censuses/surveys
    -   Data from 2004 to 2020
    -   138 countries with data
:::

$$\color{blue}{log(R_{it})}=\alpha + \beta \color{green}{Sources_{it}} + \gamma_1 \color{purple}{Pop_{it}} + \gamma_2 \color{purple}{GDP \_ pcap_{it}} + \color{orange}{c_i} + \color{brown}{\eta_t}  + \epsilon_{it} $$

## Conclusions

-   Paper suggests a methodology for measuring data use by academia

-   NLP model classifies data use with 87% accuracy

-   Results correlate strongly with other results in literature and development outcomes

-   Producing more surveys leads to more academic output

-   Scores can help countries understand if statistical system producing data that meets needs of users
